awd_titl_txt: Avian Influenza: Modeling, Analysis and Implications for Control
awd_abstract_narration:
This interdisciplinary study integrates the efforts of mathematicians and biologists in developing models and addressing questions related to the complex ecology and evolution of avian influenza. Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) of the subtype H5N1, which now threatens to mutate and cause a major pandemic, evolves from the low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) while circulating in poultry. Understanding evolution of viral pathogens requires a detailed analysis of interactions between different genetic types of the virus in the context of host population structure. The first part of this project studies the interplay of HPAI and LPAI in wild birds and domestic birds, particularly questions related to the cross-immunity that LPAI potentially provides to HPAI. The principal investigator and her colleagues develop and analyze multi-strain age-structured models in a two-host-species system (corresponding to domestic bird stocks, and wild bird populations) to study competitive exclusion and persistence of HPAI and LPAI strains.   Furthermore,  mathematical techniques are developed  that elucidate the dynamical behavior of the system. Preliminary results suggest that time-since-recovery structure coupled with cross-immunity may be responsible for more complex, oscillatory behavior of LPAI and HPAI  when there is coexistence in birds. The second part of the project builds  on these models to study the symbiotic effect of multiple control strategies applied to control highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza in poultry.   Preliminary results suggest that strategies applied to poultry, such as vaccination and culling, should be significantly more efficient than strategies applied to humans, such as wearing protective gear, in reducing the prevalence of H5N1 among humans.   Further efforts are made  to understand the interplay of vaccination of poultry and culling as the two primary control measures applied today, in order to provide quantitative insight into alternative potential measures of disease control.

This project produces models of highly pathogenic avian influenza (bird flu, caused by an H5N1 influenza virus) that are well-grounded in the complex biology of the virus and validated with available data. Such models are required both to understand the basic disease dynamics, and to develop and implement effective control measures. The models are designed to fit available data on the cumulative number of human H5N1 cases and to be able to perform reasonable projections of future cases. Furthermore, the threat of a world-wide human epidemic (pandemic) caused by H5N1 requires strict control measures for the virus. These control measures (especially culling, the killing of all birds in a poultry operation when H5N1 infection is detected) cause significant economic losses in the poultry industry in many parts of the world. The models and methods developed as a part of this project evaluate the effectiveness of alternative control measures in reducing the number of H5N1 human cases.   Analysis of these mathematical models expands our ability to choose the best control measures. In addition, the project studies the emergence of highly pathogenic strains from low pathogenic strains and their circulation in wild birds and domestic birds. The evolution of highly pathogenic strains capable of infecting humans is a major pathway through which a pandemic strain can emerge. Understanding the circumstances that foster such evolution increases our preparedness in identifying and combating potential pandemic threats caused by avian influenza.

por.por_cntn:
Avian influenza (bird flu) is a disease that affects wild and domestic birds, causing large economic losses in poultry. It can spread to humans, sometimes causing death, and with sufficient human-to-human transmission it could cause a pandemic (worldwide epidemic). Since earlier influenza pandemics have killed millions of people, understanding bird flu and methods of controlling its spread is important, and was the focus of this award.

We developed mathematical models of avian influenza and tested them against data on human cases and, for some models, poultry cases of avian influenza. Our research led to a number of insights into the complex dynamics of avian influenza. In particular, our models suggest that in the current scenario in which avian influenza is not efficiently transmitted between humans, culling poultry without re-population is the most efficient way to control the spread of avian influenza, followed by poultry vaccination and culling with re-population.  In general, measures applied to poultry are much more efficient than control measures applied to humans (such as isolating infected humans) at controlling the spread of bird flu. Of course, some control measures applied to humans are meant to protect them and therefore are still important. 

Our research results also suggested that, in an event of pandemic, vaccination of people against human flu can actually increase the ability of the avian pandemic strain to spread. Therefore, mass vaccination of people against human flu in the event of an avian flu pandemic is questionable.

 

Avian flu is transmitted to people mostly from contact with birds. However, in the period 2003-2006, there were a number of cases of human-to-human transmission, mostly within families. A pandemic can occur when each infected person infects (on average) at least one other person. Using data on the bird-to-human and human-to-human cases and employing four distinct methods, we found that each infected person infected on average only 0.2 other people. In other words, approximately 5 people infected by birds produced one secondary human case. The development of this methodology allows us to monitor how close we are to the emergence of a pandemic strain.

 

In general temporary control measures, which cease after a period of time, produce temporary results. However, sometimes in complex systems, temporary control measures can lead to lasting improvements. We found that this is more likely to occur if strong control measures are applied early in the epidemic.

 

Without using specific data, we considered the impact of air travel on the effectiveness of the control measures in an event of pandemic. We found that which control measures were most effective depended on the intensity of travel between cities. Finally, we found that combining multiple control measures and restricting travel to appropriate cities is a promising strategy for eradicating pandemic influenza.

 

This award resulted in 19 published articles with 5 in progress. Furthermore, PIs and students gave 37 talks (professional meetings, seminars and colloquia) and organized six special sessions at major conferences. This award supported the training of 3 PhD students who wrote their PhD dissertations on avian influenza and 3 undergraduate students who continued their education to graduate school.  A graduate textbook, “An Introduction to Mathematical Epidemiology,” was published, which contains a chapter on avian influenza modeling and data fitting. Three websites were developed, one each at the University of Florida, the University of Tulsa and Florida Atlantic University, containing data on avian influenza, fits of models to data, and software that performs fittings. PIs developed and taught new classes focused on Mathematical Biology and Mathematical Epidemiology that involved modules on avian influenza.
